sections.heading: 1 Abstract
sections.text:
2 Biomaterial topography-based strategy is regarded as an effective way to 3 regulate osteoimmune environment which plays an indispensable role in bone 4 regeneration process. The rapid development of manufacture techniques makes it 5 possible to investigate the cell-topography interactions by preparing various micro 6 and nano-topographical surfaces on biomaterials. Still, it is a challenge to prepare 7 well-defined micro/nano hierarchical structures of bioceramics due to the inherent 8 brittleness of ceramic materials. Also, the correlation between 9 osteoimmunomodulation initiated by micro/nano hierarchical topographies and the 10 tissue regeneration outcomes is unclear. In this study, we prepared well-defined 11 micro/nano hierarchical structures on hydroxyapatite (HA) bioceramics through the 12 combination of the photolithography and hydrothermal techniques. Three different 13 microscale circular patterns (4 μm, 12 μm and 36 μm) and nanotopographies 14 (nanoneedle, nanosheet and nanorod) were fabricated by changing the size of mask 15 and the condition of the hydrothermal reaction. The macrophage responses on the 16 nanoneedle structures with different micropatterns were investigated and the 17 micro/nano hierarchical structures with appropriate pattern size could either promote 18 or alleviate the macrophage polarization, which further affected the outcomes of the 19 osteogenic differentiation of human bone marrow stromal cells (hBMSCs) and 20 angiogenic acticvity of human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs). Our study 21 demonstrated that the osteoimmunomodulation could be manipulated via tuning the 22 micro/nano hierarchical structures, which could lead to a new strategy for the 23 development of bone biomaterials with favorable osteoimmunomodulatory properties.
24 Keywords Micro/nano hierarchical structure, Macrophage, Immunomodulation, 25 Osteogenesis, Angiogenesis

sections.heading: 1 1. Introduction
sections.text:
2 The host immune response plays a vital role in mediating implant performance 1. The 3 inflammation initiated by implanted biomaterials markedly affects the wound healing 4 and tissue remodeling process, and a beneficial immune microenvironment modulated 5 by biomaterials would guarantee the long-term success of implantation 2. Particularly, 6 macrophages, one of the predominant immune cells as well as the first defense of the 7 immune system, play a key role in both eliciting inflammatory responses and 8 orchestrating tissue repair 3, 4, and have been widely used to investigate the 9 immunomodulatory properties of biomaterials. In response to different 10 microenvironment, macrophages polarize towards different phenotypes including 11 pro-inflammatory (M1) and pro-healing (M2) polarization, which could result in 12 totally different effects on tissue repair 5-7. 13 It has been suggested that the physicochemical properties, such as surface topography, 14 rigidity and electric property of implants can stimulate the immune cells, and further 15 regulate the biological functions, which stands out as a promising way to manipulate 16 the immunomodulation and obtain favorable regeneration outcomes 8, 9. Particularly, 17 the modification on surface topography attracted much attention on achieving 18 favorable immunomodulation to affect immune cell function in vitro and tissue 19 formation in vivo 10-13. Advances in micro and nanofabrication technologies have 20 promoted the generation of a diverse range of well-defined micro or nano 21 topographies on biomaterials, and topographies with different scales seem to have 22 various immunomodulatory effects 14-18. For example, V. Malheiro et al. reported that

1 micro-scaled concave and convex surfaces significantly influence the macrophage 2 shape and size, but no relevance was found with the cell polarization status 14. Similar 3 results were found in Singh’s work as no clear shift in cell activation towards M1 or 4 M2 phenotypes on different micropatterns using conventional phenotyping methods 5 15. On the contrary, in comparison with microtopographies, nanotopographies are 6 more reliable in modulating macrophage phenotypes. The typical nanotopographical 7 surface on biomaterials such as titania nanotubes or electrospun nanofibers has been 8 reported to mediate the polarization of macrophage as a key regulator to minimize the 9 foreign-body response and enhance material's ability of tissue regeneration both in 10 vitro and in vivo 13, 16-18. Despite micro topographies and nano topographies, the 11 micro/nano combined hierarchical structures showed synergistically stimulated 12 bioactivity on stem cells as compared to the sole factor of micro topography or nano 13 topography in recent studies, which provided a valuable strategy to endow the 14 implants with enhanced tissue remodeling performance 19-21. However, the effect of 15 micro/nano hierarchical topographies of biomaterials especially bioceramics on 16 immune response has rarely been studied due to the inherent brittleness of ceramic 17 materials, which make them extremely difficult for micro and nanofabrication 22. 18 Recently, Xia et al. utilized α-tricalcium phosphate as precursors to fabricate the 19 hydroxyapatite (HA) scaffolds with micro/nano hybrid surfaces via hydrothermal 20 treatment method 20. Nevertheless, the micro/nano hybrid structures were untailored 21 and the diameter of the microrods was limited to few microns. Zhao et al. exploited a 22 simple method to acquire micro/nano hybrid structures on HA bioceramics through

1 the combination of template masking and hydrothermal treatment processes 19. 2 Although the microscale could be adjusted by the size of the nylon mask, the surface 3 morphologies of the sintered ceramics were inelegant and the boundaries of the 4 micropattern were obscure. Hence, advanced techniques are urgently needed to 5 fabricate the controllable and exquisite micro/nano hierarchical structures including 6 controllable patterns. Moreover, the correlation between osteoimmunomodulation 7 initiated by micro/nano hierarchical topographies and the tissue regeneration 8 outcomes need to be further clarified. Specific to bone tissue regeneration, 9 osteoimmunomodulation have been proved as an essential biological property of bone 10 grafts for regulating bone remodeling process 12. Hydroxyapatite (Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2), a 11 widely used bone regeneration biomaterials, possesses excellent osteoconductivity 12 and the similar chemical composition as nature bone 23, 24. 13 In this study, we developed a new approach by combining the photolithography and 14 hydrothermal techniques together to prepare HA bioceramics with well-defined and 15 patterned hierarchical surface, which contained different micropatterns and 16 nanostructures. And then, we investigated the immunomodulatory effects of the 17 micro/nano hierarchical structures on the macrophage and the osteogenic effects of 18 the activated osteoimmune environment on human bone marrow stromal cells 19 (hBMSCs) as well as the angiogenic effects on human umbilical vein endothelial cells 20 (HUVECs). It is expected that this study could signify the osteoimmunomodulatory 21 effects of micro/nano hierarchical structures and contribute to the potential application 22 of topography-based strategies in designing bioceramics for bone tissue regeneration.

1 2 2. Materials and methods 3 2.1. Fabrication and characterization of HA bioceramics with exquisite 4 micro/nano hierarchical structures 5 In order to acquire the controlled and exquisite structure on the surface of HA 6 bioceramics, the discs with the dimension of Ф 20 mm  2 mm were firstly prepared 7 by uniaxial pressing HA powder (Kunshan Huaqiao New Materials Co., Ltd, 8 Shanghai, China) with little polyvinyl alcohol as binder at 200 MPa followed by 9 sintering at 1100 °C for 3 h. The obtained HA discs were further polished to reach the 10 thickness of 1.5 mm to ensure the super smooth surface of HA samples, and then the 11 micro/nano hierarchical topographies were fabricated by virtue of photolithography 12 technique and hydrothermal method as shown in Fig. 1. Briefly, the photoresist (AZ 13 1500, AnZhi, China) was spin coated on polished HA bioceramics at the speed of 14 5000 rpm for 30s, followed with prebaking in oven at 90 °C for 30 min. Then, the 15 dried samples were subjected to UV exposure at the wavelength of 365 nm with 16 masks (Shanghai Institute of Microsystem and Information Technology, China) for 5 17 minutes followed with plasma etching to remove residual photoresist in the microdots. 18 In this study, controllable position and size of the microdots were prepared through 19 selecting masks with three different sizes (4 μm, 12 μm and 36 μm). Furthermore, 20 hydrothermal treatment with different aqueous system (Supplementary material, 21 Table 1) at 120 °C for 6 h was utilized for generating the different nanostructures on 22 the micropatterned surface of HA bioceramics. In addition, HA bioceramics with the

1 single nanostructure were also fabricated by hydrothermal treatment. All samples 2 were cleaned by ultrasound in acetone for 30 min to remove residual photoresist and 3 rinsed with enough ethanol to obliterate residual acetone. 4 The phase of the nanostructures was determined by using X-ray diffraction analysis 5 (D8 Advance, Bruker, Germany). The dried samples were analyzed by field emission 6 scanning electron microscopy (SEM: Hitachi S-4800, Japan). The stereostructures of 7 the hierarchical structures were observed though a three-dimensional (3D) measuring 8 laser microscope (LEXT: OLS4000, Olympus, Japan). Also, the surface roughness 9 (average roughness (Sa) and root mean square roughness (Sq)) of HA bioceramics 10 with different topographical surfaces was examined from the 3D images. 11 Furthermore, the wettability of HA bioceramics with the micro/nano hierarchical 12 topographies was evaluated by measuring the contact angles (Kruss, Kruss GmbH 13 Germany), and the average contact angle was finally obtained from four samples each 14 group. 15 2.2. Cell culture 16 In the study, three cells types, the murine-derived macrophage cell line RAW 264.7 17 cells, human bone marrow stromal cells (hBMSCs), and human umbilical vein 18 endothelial cells (HUVECs), were purchased from Cell Bank of the Chinese Academy 19 of Sciences. RAW 264.7 cells were cultured in Dulbecco’s modified Eagle’s medium 20 (DMEM, Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS, 21 Gibco, USA) and 1% (v/v) penicillin/streptomycin (PS, Life Technologies, USA), 22 hBMSCs were cultured in the Basal Medium for human mesenchymal stem cells

1 (Cyagen, USA) with 10% FBS and 1% PS, and HUVECs were cultured with 2 endothelial cell medium (ECM, ScienCell, USA). All cells were grown in a 3 humidified atmosphere with 5% CO2 at 37 oC and subcultured by 0.25% 4 trypsin/EDTA (Gibco, USA) until they became approximately 80%. 5 2.3. The effect of the micro/nano hierarchical topographies on macrophages 6 2.3.1 Cell morphology 7 To characterize the effect of the different topographies on macrophages morphology, 8 RAW 264.7 cells with a density of 3104 cells per well were seeded on HA samples 9 into 48-well culture plates. After 24 h of culture, RAW 264.7 cells on HA samples 10 were fixed in 2.5% glutaraldehyde and then were dehydrated by ethanol with different 11 concentration (30, 50, 75, 85, 95, and 100%) for SEM observation. 12 2.3.2 Flow cytometry 13 Flow cytometry was used to characterized M1 and M2 macrophage phenotypes by 14 determining the expression of M1 marker CD80 and M2 marker CD206, respectively. 15 RAW 264.7 cells were seeded on HA samples with a density of 30104 cells per well 16 in 6-well culture plates. After 3 days of culture, the cells were digested and rinsed 17 twice with phosphate-buffered saline (PBS). Then, the cells were incubated in PBS 18 with FITC conjugated anti-mouse CD80 antibody (1:50, BioLegend, USA) and FITC 19 conjugated anti-mouse CD206 (MMR) antibody (1:400, BioLegend, USA) at 4 °C for 20 30 min in the dark. The labeled cells were rinsed twice with PBS and then were 21 measured by flow cytometer (BD Accuri C6, USA). RAW 264.7 cells without adding 22 antibody were used as negative control. Each experiment was performed in triplicate.

sections.heading: 1 2.3.3 Quantitative Real-time PCR analysis
sections.text:
2 RAW 264.7 cells were seeded on HA samples in 6-well culture plates with a density 3 of 30104 cells per well. After 48 h of incubation, the medium in 6-well culture plates 4 was collected and centrifuged to obtain the supernatant as the conditioned medium for 5 further hBMSCs and HUVECs. After 3 days of incubation, total RNA was extracted 6 using Trizol reagent (Invitrogen, USA). Complementary DNA (cDNA) was 7 reverse-transcribed with PrimeScript RT reagent Kit (Takara, China). Quantitative 8 Real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) reactions were performed using SYBR Premix Ex Taq™ 9 (Takara, China) for the following genes: CC-chemokine receptor 7 (CCR7), inducible 10 nitric oxide synthase (iNOS), Tumor Necrosis Factor-alpha (TNF-), Arginase 1 11 (Arg-1), Cluster of Differentiation 206 (CD206), and interleukin-10 (IL-10). Relative 12 gene expression was normalized to the housekeeping gene 13 glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDH) by the ΔΔCt method. 14 Sequences of primers used in this study are listed in supplementary material (Table 2). 15 2.4. Osteogenic differentiation of hBMSCs under the modulation of the 16 topographies/macrophage microenvironment 17 The special culture medium for hBMSCs was firstly prepared by 2-fold diluting 18 conditioned medium collected in section 2.3.3 with fresh basal medium. To further 19 evaluate the role of the different topographies/macrophage-modulated osteoimmune 20 environment played in the osteogenic differentiation of hBMSCs, hBMSCs were 21 seeded in 6-well plates with a density 30104 cells per well in basal medium. After 12 22 h of incubation, the basal medium in 6-well plates was removed and substituted with

1 the special culture medium to further incubate 3 days. Ultimately, the related 2 osteogenic genes: bone morphogenetic protein-2 (BMP2), Collagen 1 (COL1), and 3 runt-related transcription factor 2 (RUNX2) were measured by qRT-PCR as described 4 in section 2.3.3. Sequences of primers used in this study are listed in supplementary 5 material (Table 2). 6 2.5. Angiogenesis analysis of HUVECs under the modulation of the 7 topographies/macrophage microenvironment 8 The special culture medium for HUVECs culture was prepared by mixing ECM and 9 collected conditioned medium at a ratio of 2:1. HUVECs were seeded in 6-well plates 10 with a density 30104 cells per well in ECM medium. After culture 12 h, the original 11 medium was removed and replaced with the special culture medium. HUVECs were 12 addressed to harvest total RNA for 3 days culture, and the related angiogenic genes: 13 endothelial nitric-oxide synthase (eNOS), vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF), 14 basic fibroblast growth factor (BFGF) were detected by qRT-PCR as described in 15 section 2.3.3. Sequences of primers used in this study are listed in supplementary 16 material (Table 2). 17 18 3. Results 19 3.1. Characterization of HA bioceramics with patterned micro/nano hierarchical 20 structures 21 The SEM analysis revealed that micro circular pattern with the size of 4 μm diameter 22 was successfully obtained on the surface of HA bioceramics through patterned

1 photoresist covering (Fig. 2a and 2e). Interestingly, the nanostructures could be 2 accurately restricted in the isolated circular pattern area which was shown in Fig. 3 1b-d. Moreover, the different nanostructures including nanoneedle (Fig. 2b and 2f), 4 nanosheet (Fig. 2c and 2g) and nanorod (Fig. 2d and 2h) were fabricated by changing 5 the hydrothermal conditions. Based on our previous study, HA with the nanoneedle 6 topography showed a better osteogenic effect compared with other nanotopographies 7 such as nanosheet 25. Hence, nanoneedle structures were chosen to combine with 8 different size of micropattern to generate the micro/nano hierarchical structures, and 9 the phase of nanoneedle was confirmed as HA phase by XRD spectra (Fig. S1). 10 As shown in Fig. 3, the polished HA bioceramics surface was smooth and flat (Fig. 11 3a) while Nano group was fully covered by nanoneedle HA with the diameter about 12 20 nm (Fig. 3b and 3g). Three different micropatterns with diameters of 4 μm, 12 μm, 13 and 36 μm filled with the similar nanoneedle structures were shown in Fig. 3c-e (High 14 magnification images were shown in Fig. S2). The diameter of 4, 12 and 36 micron 15 were chosen based on the sizes of RAW 264.7 cells which are about 10 micron when 16 fully spread. 17 The corresponding groups were named as Flat (Fig. 3a), Nano (Fig. 3b), 4-Nano (Fig. 18 3c), 12-Nano (Fig. 3d), and 36-Nano (Fig. 3e), respectively. The height of each micro 19 island was about 5 μm (Fig. 3f). 20 The hydrophilicity was assessed through the water contact angle test (Fig. S3). 21 Significant improvement of hydrophilicity was found in the group of Nano (84.5°  22 2.6°), 12-Nano hierarchical structure (82.4°  3.2°) and 36-Nano hierarchical

1 structure (80.8°  2.9°) as compared to the Flat group (96.0°  2.1°). Contrarily, the 2 4-Nano hierarchical structure showed significant hydrophobicity (107.3°  2.1°) as 3 compared with all other groups. 4 The stereostructures of the fabricated micro/nano hierarchical structures were further 5 characterized using 3D laser measuring microscope (Fig. S4). The values of Sa and 6 Sq on group of Nano and all micro/nano hierarchical structures were significantly 7 larger than those on flat surface. In addition, the roughness increased with the increase 8 of micropattern size and group of 36-Nano possessed the roughest surface. 9 3.2. The effect of the micro/nano hierarchical structures on macrophages
10 morphology 11 As shown in SEM images (Fig. 4), cell morphology could be intuitively observed, and 12 cells exhibited apparent difference on different topographies. RAW 264.7 cells seeded 13 on Flat group (Fig. 4a1-a3) showed a more elongated spindle shape as compared to 14 cells seeded on groups of Nano (Fig. 4b1-b3), 12-Nano (Fig. 4d1-d3), and 36-Nano 15 (Fig. 4e1-e3). Cells cultured on Nano group showed more homogeneously rounded 16 shape (Fig. 4b3) while different distributions of cells on micro/nano hierarchical 17 structures showed different morphologies. Cells seeded on 4-Nano group occupied 18 several circular regions (Fig. 4c1-c3) and exhibited an ultra spread shape (Fig. 4c3). 19 Cells seeded on 12-Nano group (Fig. 4d1-d3) had a similar size as the micropattern 20 and more rounded cells were observed when they were contacted with the nanoneedle 21 structure (Fig. 4d3). A similar trend was shown in the group of 36-Nano (Fig. 4e1-e3), 22 as cells on the flat region were spread and cells on micro/nano isolate were round

1 (Fig. 4e3). The shape difference of cells seeded on the different surfaces revealed that 2 the topographies could change the cells shapes. 3 3.3. Inflammatory responses of macrophages on the micro/nano hierarchical 4 structures 5 To investigate the polarization response of macrophages on the micro/nano 6 hierarchical structures, the proportion of M1-polarized and M2-polarized of RAW 7 264.7 cells was examined by flow cytometry (Fig. 5). The fluorescence intensity of 8 M1 marker CD80 and M2 marker CD206 was calculated (Fig. 5a). The result 9 revealed that Nano, 12-Nano, and 36-Nano induced much less M1 macrophages (Fig. 10 5b) and much more M2 macrophages than Flat and 4-Nano (Fig. 5c). Furthermore, 11 RAW 246.7 cells cultured on 36-Nano expressed the weakest fluorescence intensity 12 of CD80 and the strongest fluorescence intensity of CD206, which had a significant 13 difference as compared with that on Nano. On the contrary, 4-Nano showed the 14 strongest stimulation in M1 polarization and the weakest stimulation in M2 15 polarization. 16 Furthermore, the expression of inflammatory related genes in RAW 264.7 cells was 17 measured by qRT-PCR (Fig. 6). The result indicated that the inflammatory genes could 18 be modulated by different surface structures, which was consistent with the result of 19 flow cytometry. The expression of the pro-inflammatory genes (CCR7, iNOS and 20 TNF-) on Nano, 12-Nano, and 36-Nano was significantly decreased as compared 21 with that on Flat group. We also found that the pro-inflammatory genes in the group 22 of 36-Nano had a lower expression as compared to the group of Nano, which

1 suggested the specific micro/nano hierarchical structures could better suppress 2 inflammatory responses of macrophages than flat and nano structures. Nevertheless, 3 in contrast to other structures, 4-Nano promoted the expression of the 4 pro-inflammatory genes, which was consistent with the result of cells morphology in 5 section 3.2. As for anti-inflammatory properties, the expression of ARG-1, CD206 6 and IL-10 was significantly up-regulated with the stimulation of the micro/nano 7 hierarchical structures, except for 4-Nano. The increase variation of the up-regulation 8 on 36-Nano was the most significant. However, a slight down-regulation could be 9 found in 4-Nano group. 10 3.4. Effect of the topographies/macrophage microenvironment on osteogenic 11 differentiation of hBMSCs and angiogenesis of HUVEC 12 To assess the effect of the immune response of macrophage on osteogenic and 13 angiogenic differentiation, the expression of related genes in hBMSCs and HUVECs 14 cultured in different conditioned medium of the structure activated RAW 264.7 cells 15 was examined (Fig. 7). The expression of osteogenic genes in hBMSCs (BMP2, 16 COL1 and RUNX2) was significantly enhanced by surface structures stimulated 17 RAW 264.7 cells groups except for 4-Nano group, while 4-Nano group showed a 18 significant inhibition as compared with Flat group. In addition, 12-Nano and 36-Nano 19 groups displayed obviously higher BMP2 and RUNX2 expression than Nano group, 20 especially in 36-Nano group, which suggested that specific micro/nano hierarchical 21 structures could promote osteogenesis via regulating the immune microenvironment.

1 Similar to the results of the osteogenic gene expression, the expression of angiogenic 2 genes (eNOS, VEGF and BFGF) was up-regulated in the conditioned media of Nano, 3 12-Nano and 36-Nano stimulated RAW 264.7 cells, which indicates the potential for 4 regulating angiogenesis by regulating the immune microenvironment of macrophages 5 using micro/nano hierarchical structures and the nanostructure. Nevertheless, 4-Nano 6 group failed to up-regulate the expression of HUVECs marker genes, which might be 7 the result of RAW 264.7 polarization towards M1 in early stage according to flow 8 cytometry analysis of gene expression analysis (Fig. 5 and Fig. 6). 9
10 4. Discussion 11 In recent studies, micro/nano hybrid structures have been fabricated on bioceramics 12 and exhibited synergistic bioactivity on osteogenesis 19, 20. For example, micro/nano 13 hybrid structures on HA bioceramics were fabricated through burning nylon mask on 14 crude HA discs and subsequently treated with hydrothermal method in our previous 15 study 19. However, the precision of the micro structures was subject to the nylon 16 masks which were usually simple in shape and bigger over 10 microns, so the patterns 17 of the sintered ceramics were accurate. Moreover, split micro/nano hierarchical 18 structures could not be obtained by this method as all micro patterned structures were 19 covered with nano structure. In this study, well-defined micro/nano hierarchical 20 structures on HA bioceramics were successfully fabricated by combining the 21 photolithography and hydrothermal techniques together, which effectively avoid the 22 defects caused by inherent hardness and brittleness of bioceramics. Three different

1 microscale masks were used to gain controllable isolated circular patterns with the 2 diameter of 4 μm, 12 μm and 36 μm, which were designed based on the size of 3 macrophage 26. Nanoscale structures in the circle could be controlled by changing the 4 condition of the hydrothermal reaction. Here, three different nanostructures 5 (nanoneedle, nanosheet, and nanorod) were prepared by adjusting the thermal aqueous 6 solution. The nanoneedle structures were chosen for further study as similar structures 7 have been proven to enhance the cell attachment, proliferation, alkaline phosphatase 8 activity, and osteogenic gene expression 20, 25, 27. 9 Generally, nanoscale topographies could easily effect cell fate due to their analogous 10 size to cell receptors as compared to microscale topographies, which usually bring in 11 the contact guidance ascribed to the corresponding scale to cells 28. Among all types 12 of cells, immune cells are the firstly involved cells when biomaterials are implanted 13 and their indispensable roles on the tissue healing progress have been widely studied 14 1, 29. As a typical immune cell, macrophages are recruited and targeted to the surface 15 of the biomaterials after implantation. They play a key role in modulating the host 16 response via collaborating with other cells such as endothelial cells, fibroblasts, and 17 osteoblasts 26, 30, 31. Moreover, macrophages can change their phenotypes and release a 18 wide spectrum of chemokines and cytokines that orchestrate tissue healing processes 19 32, 33. Classical phenotypes including pro-inflammatory (M1) and pro-healing (M2) 20 polarization as well as other phenotypes are determined and activated by immune 21 microenvironment which can be tailored by implanted biomaterials 34. Significant M2 22 polarization activated by different topographies was observed in many studies and the

1 further immunomodulatory microenvironment usually showed a positive effect on 2 tissue healing process, which attracts the attention of the researchers for 3 topography-based strategies 9, 35, 36. Although the polarization effect of 4 microtopographies is controversial, the morphology changes of macrophages on the 5 microtopographical surface were observed in many studies and the polarization 6 effects of nanotopographies on macrophage were widely reported 14, 15, 18, 37. Bai et al. 7 reported that micro/nano hybrid coating on titanium could inhibit the inflammatory 8 response of macrophages and enabled a favorable osteoimmunomodulation to 9 facilitate osteo/angio-genesis 38. However, the effect of bioceramics with micro/nano 10 hierarchical topographies on macrophage has rarely been studied due to the challenge 11 of the fabrication technique. Here for the first time we elucidated the effect of 12 bioceramics micro/nano surface on macrophages and found that the cell morphologies 13 on different micro/nano hierarchical structures were significantly different. More 14 round-shaped macrophages were observed on groups of Nano, 12-Nano hierarchical 15 structure and 36-Nano hierarchical structure. Although the relationship between 16 macrophage phenotype and cell shape is controversial 26, 33, the finding of the present 17 study was consistent with the rule that round-shaped macrophages induced by pure 18 Nano and Nano combined with larger micropatterns showed more anti-inflammatory 19 tendency, which was confirmed by the result of flow cytometry (Fig. 5) and gene 20 expression of M2 markers like ARG-1, CD-206, and IL-10 (Fig. 6). To be specific, 21 the nanoneedle structured HA surface induced the M2 polarization of macrophages, 22 and the micro/nano hierarchical structures with the micropattern size of 12 μm and 36

1 μm even more significantly enhanced M2 polarization of macrophages as compared to 2 HA bioceramics with nanostructures only. However, the group of 4-nano hierarchical 3 structures exhibited opposite effect on stimulating macrophage to the M1 phenotype. 4 Considering the structural difference between Nano, 4-Nano, 12-Nano and 36-Nano 5 samples, it is clear to see the importance of the micro-sized patterns, since the four 6 groups all have similar nano-structure, but different micropatterns including the size 7 and distance of the pattern islands, and in particular the distance of the islands might 8 play a more important role to regulate cells since the island distance in 4-Nano is 9 smaller than the size of a cell and that of the 12-Nano and 36-Nano are larger than the 10 size of a cell. Another possible reason for the different effect of 4-Nano group might 11 be the increased hydrophobicity of 4-Nano group as compared with other groups. A 12 previous study has shown that higher hydrophobicity is more likely to induce 13 macrophage polarization to M1 phenotype by controlling fibrinogen adsorption and 14 conformation which would activate NF-κB signaling pathways through selective 15 expression of integrin β2 39. This result also indicates that the structural optimization 16 is critical for designing bioceramics for regulating immune microenvironment. 17 In-depth studies are needed in the future study to disclose the underlying mechanism 18 of interaction between the micro/nano hierarchical structures and the macrophage. 19 Previous studies have found that HA bioceramics with micro/nano hierarchical 20 structured surface are able to directly stimulate the osteogenic function of stem cell in 21 vitro and enhance bone formation in vivo 19, 20, 27. However, in a bone graft 22 implantation situation, not only MCSs but also immune cells involved, and

1 macrophages might be one of the first occurring cell type around the implants. 2 Therefore, the activation of macrophages and the effect of macrophage activation on 3 osteogenesis are important for understanding the mechanisms of the interaction of 4 bone implant biomaterials with the bone defect microenvironment. Our study now 5 provided a new perspective that micro/nano hierarchical structures may enhance the 6 bone regeneration through manipulating the polarization of macrophages. To testify 7 this hypothesis, hBMSCs were treated with topographical surface/macrophage 8 conditioned medium compared with the polished surface/macrophage conditioned 9 medium. Consistent with macrophage polarization study, the expression of the 10 osteogenic gene such as BMP2, COL1, and RUNX2 of hBMSCs was upregulated in 11 groups of Nano, 12-Nano hierarchical structure and 36-Nano hierarchical structure 12 compared with the flat structure. The medium conditioned by 12-Nano hierarchical 13 structure or 36-Nano hierarchical structure showed higher expression of BMP2 and 14 RUNX2 of hBMSCs genes as compared to the nanotopographical structure. These 15 results may attribute to the healing immune microenvironment aroused by the 16 activated and M2 polarized macrophage as all groups containing nanotopographies 17 stimulated M2 polarization of macrophages except for the 4-Nano group. 18 Correspondingly, 4-Nano conditioned medium suppressed the osteogenesis of 19 hBMSCs due to the generated immune microenvironment as indicated by M1 20 polarization. 21 During the bone regeneration process, vascularization is an essential stage as new 22 vasculatures were needed to provide nutrition and carry away the waste 40. Here, we

1 also investigated the angiogenic effect of the macrophage polarization stimulated by 2 nano and micro-surface structure of bioceramics. HUVECs were treated with 3 conditioned media of different structural activated macrophages, and the results 4 showed that the expression of angiogenesis-related genes such as eNOS, VEGF and 5 BFGF was up-regulated by Nano, 12-Nano hierarchical structure and 36-Nano 6 hierarchical structure/macrophage conditioned media as compared to flat 7 structure/macrophage conditioned medium while 4-Nano group even showed slight 8 inhibition of some angiogenic gene expression. These results indicate that the 9 structural regulation of macrophages indeed also affected angiogenesis potential of 10 endothelia cells, which suggest that the biomaterial structure regulates angiogenesis 11 during tissue regeneration through a multi-pathway mechanism including direct 12 stimulation of endothelia cells and indirect stimulation by activating macrophages. 13 Osteogenesis and angiogenesis are delicately concerted during lifelong bone 14 formation and increasing studies have demonstrated that immune microenvironment 15 could directly modulate the development of osteogenesis and angiogenesis 9, 26, 41, 42. 16 Therefore, biomaterials with favorable osteoimmunomodulatory properties are 17 drawing more attention and surface topographies are regarded as promising cues. 18 Despite widely studied nanotopographies, micro/nano hybrid structures had also been 19 investigated in Bai’s study which showed that microporous TiO2 coating decorated 20 with hydroxyapatite (HA) nanoparticles could inhibit the inflammatory response of 21 macrophages and enabled a favorable osteoimmunomodulation to facilitate 22 osteo/angio-genesis 38. However, the effect of micro/nano hierarchical topographies

1 on bioceramics on immune response has not been reported. Our study demonstrated 2 that the micro/nano hierarchical structures on bioceramics could also regulate the 3 inflammatory response of macrophages and further impact on osteogenesis and 4 angiogenesis. Thus, topography modulation would be a novel strategy for developing 5 advanced biomaterials with favorable osteoimmunomodulatory properties. 6 7 5. Conclusion 8 The micro/nano hierarchical structures have been successfully fabricated directly on 9 HA bioceramics by photolithography combined with hydrothermal method, and the 10 nanoneedle structure could be precisely controlled to grow in convex micron circles 11 with the diameter of 4, 12, and 36 μm, respectively. In the study, the surface 12 structures have been demonstrated to regulate immune cell response. The micro/nano 13 hierarchical structures with appropriate pattern size could either promote the 14 polarization of macrophages to M1 or M2, showing more flexibility as compared with 15 sole nanostructure. In addition, the expressions of osteogenic genes of hBMSCs and 16 angiogenic genes of HUVECs could further be regulated by topographical 17 surface/macrophage conditioned medium as corresponding to the pro-healing immune 18 environment or the pro-inflammatory immune environment. Our results suggested 19 that different structures could influence different osteoimmune environments for 20 improving subsequent osteogenesis, and the micro/nano hierarchical structures have 21 the potential to promote better bone regeneration via generating a favorable immune 22 environment for osteogenesis.
